message: Join Congressman Ken Buck for a town hall in Burlington! If you have questions or comments for the Congressman this is a great chance to engage with him directly. The event will be held in the Carousel Park.
Yesterday, I voted against the proposed changes to the Office of Congressional Ethics. For more information on what's going on in Washington, don't hesitate to call my office at (202)-225-4676.

The House Rules Committee is holding its first meeting of the 115th Congress today. I'm honored to be a part of this important committee as we fight for America's future.  Watch the meeting live here: https://rules.house.gov/video/organizational-meeting-115th-congress-hr-26-hres-11
Talking about the future of our country right now on 710 KNUS with Steve and Krista.

With his term coming to a close, President Obama has been issuing dozens of new administrative rules that mean more red tape for citizens and small businesses. That's why the House passed the Midnight Rules Relief Act today, a bill that enables us to roll back several of his last minute regulations at once.
With just about two weeks left in President Obama's presidency, I wrote an op-ed urging him not to place bureaucrats in control of millions of acres of America's heartland.   What are your thoughts?

If the federal government is going to implement a regulation that costs America millions of dollars, then the people's representatives in Congress should have a say. That's why I voted for the REINS Act tonight. This bill allows Congress to weigh in on any new executive branch rule that costs the economy more than $100 million annually. #REINSAct

I voted yesterday for a resolution that rebukes the United Nation’s unwarranted condemnation of Israel. While I strongly believe Congress did the right thing by standing up for our strongest Middle East ally, I am opposed to the language that recognizes a two-state solution. Only the countries directly affected by the agreement should dictate the terms of peace. The United States, United Nations, and other world powers should not interfere.

Monday is Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, our chance to honor the men and women who serve in uniform every day.   Today, I sent a letter to Governor Hickenlooper asking him to illuminate the State Capitol in blue light on Monday night to honor Colorado law enforcement.

It's National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day. I have candles in my office windowsill tonight to send a message to our Law Enforcement: "We stand with you. We will always stand with you." #SupportBlue

The Iran Deal has always been a mess, but now Iran is actually being rewarded for breaking the terms of the agreement!  https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/right-turn/wp/2017/01/10/one-final-iran-blunder-by-obama/?utm_term=.f2f06657cfc1
Yesterday, I joined 343 of my colleagues in the House to pass legislation making it easier for angel investors to fund startups.

Today I voted for the Regulatory Accountability Act of 2017. This legislation is actually a collection of six different, previously passed bills that all address overreaching federal regulations, from requiring agencies to select the lowest-cost alternative when making rules and to reduce the impact of new rules on small business to making it easier for the public to access and comment on new rule proposals.

I co-sponsored H.R. 400, the Stop Dangerous Sanctuary Cities Act. This legislation withholds federal funding from jurisdictions where local law enforcement are not permitted to work with federal immigration officials to enforce federal immigration law. These laws are meant to protect citizens, and cities should be working with federal law enforcement to ensure the rule of law is upheld.

Today I introduced the WATER Act for the 115th Congress. Last year I fought hard to see this bill through the legislative process, and was able to see it out of committee. This year I'm eager to see passage in the House and Senate and a signature from the President. The legislation makes water more affordable for farmers, ranchers, and anyone who lives in rural Colorado. Here's a video I put together last year about the bill:

My heart goes out to the office of Rep. Elijah Cummings after the devastating tragedy suffered by one of his staff members due to a house fire this week. I'm praying for the family and Rep. Cumming's office as they cope with this loss.

Today I voted to repeal and replace Obamacare. We need to replace Obamacare with a market-oriented alternative that makes healthcare affordable for all Coloradans. At the same time, we need to ensure that there are no coverage lapses during the transition and that those who have access to coverage now don't lose it. Please visit my website to share you ideas about how to make healthcare better in this country.   https://buck.house.gov/share
Remembering today one of America's great leaders and what he stood for.
We're drowning in debt. There are better ways to spend this $500 million.

My staff will be holding mobile office hours this week throughout Southeastern Colorado. If you want to share your concerns or need help navigating federal programs and bureaucratic red tape, feel free to stop by. Check the link for details:
Had a great meeting yesterday with many folks from the agriculture community. I'm looking forward to holding many more of these around the district.
Last week I introduced the WATER Act to help farmers, ranchers, and all of rural Colorado. Here's some more information on it:

Today I visited North Star Academy, a charter school in Parker. I met some great kids who I'm confident will make big contributions to our state and the world.   My visit was in anticipation of National School Choice Week, which starts on Sunday. I support giving parents and students educational choice because it's the best way to ensure all students have access to quality education opportunities.
Here's another photo from my visit to North Star Academy yesterday. I spoke to dozens of 7th and 8th graders about the importance of having an education system that teaches character.

I was honored to attend, with hundreds of thousands of other Americans, the inauguration of President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence. I'm excited to work with the President and my colleagues here in Washington to advance policy that puts America back on track.

I’m thankful President Trump signed executive orders today to move forward with the construction of the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines. We’ve been waiting a long time for the jobs and economic growth that will come along with these projects.

Has your family been impacted by Obamacare? Are you struggling with higher premium prices, forced doctor changes, or lack of insurance options? I want to hear your story. Please share it with my office through the link below.

I signed on to a letter today urging President Trump to fill the vacancies at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC). This commission is so important because it reviews applications to build interstate natural gas pipelines and liquefied natural gas terminals. In March of last year, FERC denied the application for the Jordan Cove Energy pipeline, a key project that would benefit Coloradans by selling natural gas to our allies abroad, thereby creating jobs across the state. We need new commissioners on FERC who will stand up for American jobs and safe energy production.

This week I voted for H.R. 7, a bill that prohibits federal dollars from funding abortions. Congress has long followed this policy, adding the Hyde Amendment to funding bills every year to assure that those with moral or religious objections to abortion don't have to contribute their tax dollars to them. This bill simply makes the Hyde Amendment permanent.

It's been a big week for the life of the unborn. We passed HR 7, a bill that prevents taxpayer dollars from being used for abortions. President Trump also reinstated the Mexico City policy which prevents U.S. aid from going to organizations that promote abortions in foreign countries. I'm eager to continue working with my colleagues and the White House to protect the life of the unborn.

I commend the President’s nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the U.S. Supreme Court to fill the vacancy created by the untimely death of Justice Antonin Scalia. I’m confident Judge Gorsuch will succeed in the Supreme Court because he holds sound judicial interpretation in such high regard. As a Coloradan, I know Mr. Gorsuch will take his common sense values with him to the nation’s highest court.
Last night my Deputy District Director, Robin Coran, attended a Court of Honor ceremony to present a letter from me that congratulated three new Eagle Scouts on their achievements.
I voted today to disapprove of the Stream Protection Rule, another last minute, excessive regulation rushed through at the end of the Obama administration. It’s time to put an end to the War on Coal.
Regulations need to be smart and reasonable. Today we repealed an Obama administration regulation that isn’t either. #HJRes36
Good reminder from President Reagan on his birthday:
February is American Heart Month, a chance to focus on awareness and prevention of heart disease. #HeartMonth

The Obama administration’s heavy-handed fiduciary rule would have made affordable financial planning advice inaccessible for Colorado families. I’m thankful that President Trump rolled back the rule today, allowing Coloradans to receive financial planning advice that helps secure a prosperous future for their families.
Several citizens of the Fourth Congressional District came to Washington for the inauguration last month and shared their thoughts about that historic day and our future legislative agenda.

Today, I voted to return control of resource management planning to local communities in Colorado. H.J. Res. 44 disapproves of a rule that placed significant planning authority in the hands of bureaucrats in the Bureau of Land Management, leaving local experts and stakeholders in Colorado out of the process.

Today I voted for two House Resolutions that roll back federal involvement in education, allowing local communities, school districts, and teachers a greater say in our school system. I’ve spoken to a lot of educators and administrators in Colorado, and I trust them more than I do federal bureaucrats to know what our children need. #HJRes57 #HJRes58
I wrote an op-ed about why the Senate needs to confirm Judge Gorsuch to the Supreme Court. Read it here:
Praying for everyone affected by this fire in Boulder County today.
NA

Next week on Thursday night (February 23rd) at 7:00 PM, I'm holding a telephone town hall to talk with constituents about issues that matter to them. If you'd like to be added to the list to receive a call around that time next week, please fill out the following form. I look forward to chatting with you.

Yesterday, the House passed the Wingman Act, legislation that allows a veteran to give congressional staff permission to view his or her Veterans Benefits Administration file. This is important because it allows my office to provide quicker answers to veterans who need help assessing the status of their benefits.   My office is dedicated to helping veterans in the Fourth Congressional District who need help navigating the Veterans Benefits Agency. If you're a veteran facing challenges with your benefits, please call my Greeley office at (970) 702-2136.

When I'm in Washington, the staff in my district office spend time meeting with constituents and hearing their concerns. Today, Luke and Erika met with Lt. Col. Arrington and a few of his JROTC cadets. They came by to talk about policy issues, specifically immigration.

Yesterday I introduced, with my friend Rep. Ted Lieu, the Political Appointee Burrowing Prevention Act. This bi-partisan legislation prevents political appointees from leveraging their position into a career civil service role. Without this bill as a safeguard, political appointees can embed across our bureaucracy, carrying on the agenda of their appointing president long after voters have chosen a new direction.

The estate tax often hits farmers and ranchers the hardest, preventing their children from receiving the land that has been passed down for generations by their families. That's why I co-sponsored H.R. 631, the Death Tax Repeal Act, this week.
Happy Presidents' Day! Today I thank our past and current presidents for their service to this nation.

I'm holding a telephone town hall on Thursday night at 7 PM to discuss policy issues with constituents. I encourage you to participate. If you'd like to be included in the call, please sign-up beforehand at the link on this page:

I was honored to attend the Farm Credit Agriculture Hall of Fame Dinner last week where we honored individuals who have made significant contributions to the agriculture community in Colorado, including my father-in-law. I presented Congressional Records for the four hall of fame inductees.
I support the President's decision to roll back the Waters of the US rule. Colorado's farmers and ranchers deserve certainty and a greater say in the regulatory framework of our waterways.

The President delivered a message last night about the renewal of the American spirit. I'm eager to work with the White House to create jobs and economic prosperity for our communities. I'm eager to work on improving public safety and national security. And I'm eager to repeal and replace Obamacare with a healthcare system that actually provides affordable healthcare.
Today I voted for the SCRUB Act (H.R. 998), legislation that creates a commission to identify excessive, costly regulations that should be repealed to promote economic growth.
Thanks to the more than 11,000 Coloradans who joined my telephone town hall last Thursday night. I look forward to the next one, which I'll announce on this page.

Legal immigration is a key asset for local businesses who need seasonal workers. But the Department of Labor is significantly delayed in processing H-2B visa applications to allow seasonal workers into the United States. That's why I signed a letter to the Acting Secretary of Labor requesting that H-2B applications be processed in a more timely manner.

I signed a letter calling on the President to quickly nominate Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) members so that FERC can begin reviewing and approving applications to build interstate natural gas pipelines and liquefied natural gas terminals.   I'm glad to see reports that President Trump is working hard to fill these vacancies. I thank him for focusing on these nominations so that we can unleash American energy and create jobs in Colorado.
I met with several members of the South Metro Denver Chamber of Commerce who visited Washington this week. We chatted about the issues impacting Colorado businesses.
I'm praying for everyone affected by the brush fire near Fleming. My office is in contact with local officials to determine how we can be of assistance.

Today my bill, the Innocent Party Protection Act, passed the House! This legislation will protect small business owners from frivolous lawsuits, enabling them to focus instead on job creation and adding value to the economy. Here's a press release with more details: https://buck.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/buck-s-innocent-party-protection-act-passes-house

With Obamacare plan sign-ups down from last year, insurers pulling out of the market, and prices soaring for many people in the Fourth Congressional District, our job of replacing Obamacare with something better is more pressing than ever. I'm fighting to ensure the final replacement plan makes coverage more affordable and accessible.

Dusty, who works in my Greeley district office, visited the areas impacted in Northeastern Colorado by the brush fires last week. We're so encouraged by the stories of how the community came together to both fight the fire and begin the recovery process. Nevertheless, several families were deeply impacted by this disaster and have a long road ahead for recovery. The Farm Service Agency within the USDA manages several disaster assistance programs that can provide help: https://www.fsa.usda.gov/contact-us

Due to the fires last week in Northeastern Colorado, the Risk Management Agency has allowed additional time for insured producers in Logan and Phillips Counties to report their wheat acres for short rate eligibility. You can find more details here: http://www.rma.usda.gov/bulletins/managers/2017/mgr-17-002.pdf

I'm encouraged by President Trump's budget proposal. We've had a spending problem in this country for too long. This plan takes a step in the right direction by trimming our discretionary budget while also ensuring that our military receives the funding they need to do their duty.

This week the House passed three bills to help our nation's veterans. H.R. 1181 prevents the VA from stripping them of their Second Amendment rights without due process. H.R. 1259 and H.R. 1367 improve the VA's ability manage personnel, ensuring that our veterans have the best people providing their care.

My office is hosting an official from the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services agency to discuss the process of applying for U.S. citizenship. The event will be held on Tuesday, March 21 at 7:00 PM at Our Lady of Peace parish in Greeley.
Today, Erika and Dusty from my district office visited the Flagler Cooperative in Genoa to hear about their policy concerns and learn more about the agriculture industry in that part of the district.

Yesterday, I offered an amendment that was added onto H.R. 1367 to prevent political appointees from burrowing into the VA. The bi-partisan fight against burrowing is important for our veterans and everyone else who is impacted by the federal government. For more details on my amendment, read this article: http://www.greeleytribune.com/news/local/amendment-by-rep-ken-buck-to-prevent-burrowing-by-va-political-appointees-passes-voice-vote/#

As Judge Neil Gorsuch participates in further Senate hearings today, I wanted to repost the article I wrote a few weeks ago. I think the judge will make a great Supreme Court justice and I encourage my Senate colleagues to confirm him quickly.
On National Ag Day, we have a chance to remember and thank the men and women who farm our nation's soil, contributing to our nation's food supply and to our communities in so many ways.

Robin on my district staff recently attended a couple Coffee with Cops meetings in Douglas County. In the first photo she's meeting with the Parker Chief of Police and several other officers. The next two photos show the K-9s who serve the Douglas County Sheriff's office. These dogs represent 2 of the 4 K-9s serving in the state of Colorado, helping law enforcement do their jobs safely and efficiently.   We need to support and protect our law enforcement, which is what I'm fighting for in Washington.

We've waited a long time for the jobs and energy security that will come along with the Keystone XL pipeline. I'm thankful the State Department issued the permit today that will allow the project to move forward.

Today, the President signed a number of important Resolutions into law that will roll back excessive regulations from the previous administration. I wanted to specifically flag the BLM Management Planning 2.0 rule for you because it impacts our state significantly. Under this rule, bureaucrats in Washington would have outsize influence on how we use the land and minerals in Colorado. Instead, these decisions should be left to local communities, which is what H.J. Res. 44 will allow.
Congratulations to Douglas County for being ranked the healthiest county in Colorado! The people and businesses of the county have worked hard to earn this distinction.

Much of our district is rural, and delivering healthcare in rural areas can be challenging. That's why I signed on to a letter asking the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to provide a full and fair review of the Keefe Memorial Hospital's Critical Access Hospital (CAH) Application. Keefe meets the CAH criteria and is critical for the Cheyenne Wells community.

Ninety percent of Americans agree that data used by the federal government to make decisions should be made public. The HONEST Act does this, giving independent scientists access to EPA data so they can validate EPA studies. We’ll all benefit from more reliable science, which is why I voted for the bill today on the House floor.

Yesterday, I voted for the Encouraging Employee Ownership Act. This legislation rolls back a regulation so that small businesses can increase the amount of stock they provide to employees as compensation, giving the employees greater ownership in the company and the employers a better chance to recruit and retain top talent.

I'm thankful the Senate confirmed Judge Neil Gorsuch, a Coloradan, to the Supreme Court today. I'm confident his thoughtfulness, Colorado values, and experience will allow him to apply the law justly, according to its original intent. Congratulations to Judge Gorsuch!
Congratulations to Justice Neil Gorsuch on his swearing-in to the U.S. Supreme Court. I look forward to the thoughtfulness and Colorado values he'll bring to the bench.

Last week I had the honor to meet the winner of the Congressional App Challenge for Colorado's Fourth Congressional District, Etash Kalra. I'm so proud of his hard work so far and his focus on coding and STEM education. His innovative app helps students practice for spelling bees.

I recently introduced important legislation that will bring greater accountability to the budgeting process in Washington, D.C. This bill would require the OMB to track the revenue actually collected from budget offsets or "payfors," and then compile this information into an annual report to Congress. Check the link below for more information.

President Trump and the Office of Management and Budget are focused on reorganizing the federal government to make it more efficient and less wasteful. They're soliciting ideas from everyone, so I encourage you to share your thoughts with the Executive Branch at the link below:

I'm thankful that President Trump signed H.J. Res. 43 into law today. This resolution repeals a last minute Obama administration regulation that would require states to fund abortion providers with their Title X dollars. Taxpayers should never be asked to fund abortion services.

National Park Week starts tomorrow! This is a great time to discover the incredible outdoor treasures that we have in Colorado and around the nation. For more information about the week and free entry to parks, visit this website: https://www.nps.gov/findapark/national-park-week.htm
Today, I'm thanking God for sending his son to redeem us, to redeem this world.

I had a great time talking to constituents today in Longmont at a town hall I was invited to attend. We covered multiple issues and had a very constructive conversation. I appreciate that citizens in the Fourth Congressional District are so civically engaged--this is the kind of passion we need for fixing the problems in our country.

I had a great policy conversation with the Greeley Indivisible group a few days ago. While we disagreed on several issues, conversations like these are vital if we're going to come together and build consensus in this country. We need to fix healthcare and pass several other important policies. Listening to our constituents during that process is incredibly important.

I recently signed on to a letter calling for VA Secretary Shulkin to further investigate the problems with the Veterans Crisis Line, a key resource for our heroes who are facing mental health issues. With nearly 20 veteran suicides a day, it's vital that this hotline is fully functioning.

"We've spent the last decade seriously debating healthcare reform in this country. But somehow, even after a decade of debate, we are still treating the symptoms and not the disease, like a doctor treating lung cancer as a bad cough."  If we're truly going to make healthcare more affordable, we need to address the factors driving the cost of care. Read the rest of my op-ed here:

Are you a resident of the Fourth Congressional District and visiting Washington, D.C. this weekend? If so, my office has a few tickets for the White House Spring Garden Tour that we can offer you! The tour takes place on Sunday, April 23rd at 2:30 P.M. Tickets will be distributed on a first-come, first-serve basis. Call my Washington, D.C. office for more information: 202-225-4676.

Republicans have been governing for almost 100 days. We still have a lot of work ahead, but we've already accomplished much. One of our most important achievements in the past several weeks has been the appointment of Justice Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court. I thank the President for nominating and the Senate for confirming a justice who will remain faithful to the Constitution and the original intent of the law.

We're approaching 100 days of Republican governance, and we've done a lot in that time. Two of the most important measures passed by the House were H.J. Res. 40 and H.R. 1181, the former of which broadly protects individuals from having their constitutional rights stripped away with due process, and the latter of which specifically protects veterans' constitutional rights from being stripped from them without due process. Our veterans sacrificed for us. The least we can do is protect their constitutional rights.  The President has signed H.J. Res. 40, and H.R. 1181 is currently under consideration in the Senate.

Republicans have been governing for nearly 100 days and we've done a lot. One of our important efforts was H.J. Res. 58, a resolution that empowers states and local school boards to create systems for keeping schools accountable to parents, taxpayers, and communities.

Robin and Erika from my Castle Rock office recently attended Fort Carson's Pinon Canyon Maneuver Site Community Day, where they learned about the operations at the site, the equipment our military uses to get the job done, and the incredible men and women who work there.

I'm thankful that the Colorado Department of Transportation  recently received a grant with additional Emergency Relief program funding to address disaster relief and mitigation projects in Colorado. I also recently co-signed a letter asking the Appropriations Committees in the House and Senate to ensure the Federal Highway Administration's Emergency Relief account is adequately funded. This funding is important as we continue to rebuild after the 2013 flooding and as we prepare for future natural disasters.

Today I voted for H.R. 1694, the Fannie and Freddie Open Records Act of 2017, which passed the House unanimously.  During the financial crisis, the government bailed out these companies with taxpayer dollars. This bill simply allows the American public to know how these companies are using these taxpaying dollars, holding Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac accountable and ensuring transparency.

Rural communities are at the heart of American values: hard work, family, kindness, authenticity. But they've also suffered over the past several years, victims of government overregulation and under-appreciation.  That's why I'm so thankful President Trump signed an executive order this week directing the federal government to convene a task force that promotes rural America.

With nearly 100 days of Republican governance under our belt, we've already accomplished a lot. One of the important resolutions passed through Congress and signed by the President was H.J. Res. 44, which repeals a regulation that gave Washington bureaucrats an outsize influence on local land use and preservation decisions. H.J. Res. 44 empowers states and local governments to make those decisions instead.

I'm thankful President Trump signed an executive order today calling for a review of several designations under the Antiquities Act. The last administration abused this law, using it to stunt economic growth and cordon off large swaths of land from use by citizens. In fact, President Obama designated more acreage under this act than all other previous presidents combined. We need to ensure that designations are in line with the purpose of the original act. Furthermore, permanent Antiquities Act designations should require consent of Congress and local legislatures, so the citizens most impacted by the designation have a say in the process.

I just offered an amendment to the Thin Blue Line Act to add the "targeting" of a law enforcement officer as an aggravating factor in consideration of enhanced punishment. Thankfully, the amendment passed the committee. This amendment and the underlying bill sends a message to those who would harm police: if you target an officer, you'll face the death penalty yourself.   This bill ensures that men like Eric Frein, who fatally shot a state trooper in Pennsylvania in 2014 and recently received the death penalty, face the full sentence they deserve for their evil actions.

Saddened by the loss of Corporal Ballard yesterday. He sacrificed everything to make his community a safe place for everyone else. We need to send a message that our country won't stand for the killing of law enforcement officers, which is why I'm thankful the Thin Blue Line Act was reported out of the House Judiciary Committee today.

For too long, the Department of Veterans Affairs has failed our veterans. That's why I'm glad the President signed an Executive Order yesterday establishing an Office of Accountability and Whistleblower Protection within the VA.
I support small businesses because they're so important to our economy and our communities. #SmallBusinessWeek

We need to craft policies in Washington that allow small businesses to thrive. With 47% of private sector employees in the U.S. working for a small business, our economy and way of life depends on it. #SmallBusinessWeek

Small Businesses create jobs. In fact, they create 63% of new jobs in this country. That's why we need federal policies that allow small businesses to focus on job growth instead of red tape and regulations.

Americans are go-getters. Hard workers. Entrepreneurs. Innovators. Problem-solvers. No wonder there are more than 29 million small businesses in this country. We need to craft policy in Washington that helps them grow and create jobs.
Just received the spending bill I'm voting on tomorrow. I'll start reading it tonight...
I'm holding a Facebook Live town hall tomorrow around 11:30 AM. I'd love to hear your questions and thoughts in the comment section. Leave them below or on the live video tomorrow.

I had a great Skype conversation today with Ms. Westfall's class at Manzanola High School, where they're playing the Stock Market Game as part of the Capitol Hill Challenge. We discussed the stock market, the economy, and what's happening on Capitol Hill. I'm proud of these students, who are learning the financial skills that will help them personally and in their careers.
Join me for a Facebook Live town hall.

It's National Teacher Appreciation Day, a chance for us to thank the men and women who spend so much of their lives investing in our children. Teachers pass academic knowledge on to our sons and daughters, but they also offer the wisdom and encouragement that will change the lives of our younger generation forever.

Join Congressman Ken Buck for a town hall in La Junta! If you have questions or comments for the Congressman this is a great chance to engage with him directly. The event will be held in the Otero Junior College, McBride Hall Room #137.

Yesterday, I met with some incredible students at University High School in Greeley to discuss the process of applying for an appointment to a U.S. military academy. I'm proud that these students are considering serving their country in the armed forces.

I recently toured and discussed important policy issues at North Colorado Medical Center's Western States Burn Center. I'm incredibly thankful for the men and women who work in this center to bring healing and wholeness back to those in our community who face the trauma of burn injuries.

I'm excited to announce the 2017 Congressional App Challenge! If you're a high schooler in the Fourth Congressional District who knows how to code or wants to learn, then this challenge is for you. The challenge accepts submissions until November 1, but it never hurts to get an early start!

National Police Week gives us a chance to honor the men and women who put on a badge every day to protect and serve our communities. They pay a high price, and some pay the highest price, so that we can live safe and prosperous lives.

I'm proud that this week the House passed the Thin Blue Line Act. I was honored to manage floor debate on this bill for the Rules Committee. This legislation makes the murder or attempted murder of a law enforcement officer or first responder an aggravating factor for Federal death penalty cases. In passing this bill, Congress is sending a clear message that America will not stand for the killing of law enforcement officers.

Last year, ambush-style killings of police officers were up by 167%. We must send a clear message to those criminals who believe it's ok to target law enforcement officers. That's why I'm thankful the House will be considering the Thin Blue Line Act this week, legislation which adds the killing or attempted killing of law enforcement or first responders as an aggravating factor in Federal death penalty cases. I have the honor of managing floor debate today for the rule resolution on this bill.   Our officers do their duty. This week we must do ours by passing the Thin Blue Line Act.

Last week I had the chance to visit Premium Powder Coating in Longmont, where we discussed issues facing the small business community. I'm focused on policies in Washington that will make it easier for businesses across Colorado to grow and add employees.

I was honored to speak at the Vietnam Veterans Ceremony in Longmont a few days ago. I'm thankful for the men and women who have sacrificed, throughout our nation's history, to fight for freedom around the world.

Join Congressman Ken Buck for a town hall in Cheyenne Wells! If you have questions or comments for the Congressman this is a great chance to engage with him directly. The event will be held in the Town of Cheyenne Wells Auditorium.

A pamphlet heralded our new democracy. Impassioned speeches fueled the abolitionists. An address on the National Mall prompted the end of segregation. We protect speech in this country because freedom and liberty can’t live without it.   This weekend, Vice President Pence offered a commencement address calling for the defense of free speech on our college campuses.   In case you missed it amidst all the coverage over the few students who walked out of the speech, I encourage you to listen to the Vice President's remarks. I'd love to know your thoughts.

I had the honor to manage debate on the House floor today for two important bills that protect children from abuse. We are all the guardians of our nation’s youth. We are all responsible for their childhood. We are all proponents of their future. That's why we need to pass these bills.

A new report from the Department of Health and Human Services shows that premiums on the federal Obamacare exchanges increased on average by 105% between 2013 and 2017. That's an average premium increase of $244 per month in those states. Obamacare is failing too many people in this country. We need to lower premiums and ensure patients and doctors are the ones making health care decisions. The AHCA is the first step in this process.

Today, we honor the men and women who have fallen fighting for our nation. We set aside one day to honor these fallen heroes, but really their memorial lives on in this country and its people, every day of the year.

Last night I had a great discussion with members of the Douglas County Voices for Action group. We talked about a number of issues, including education, fiscal responsibility and the budget, healthcare, national security, and several local issues. We didn't agree on everything but I'm thankful we could have a conversation about the issues.

Yesterday, I toured the Greeley Refugee Center to learn about the issues faced by people newly arrived in our communities and how the center helps those individuals transition to life in America and successfully contribute to our society.

I had the chance to speak with the Castle Rock Rotary Club this morning about current legislative issues facing the country. I'm encouraged by the way the club serves the Castle Rock community and I appreciated their policy input at breakfast this morning.

Yesterday, I toured the Chick-Fil-A on Metzler Drive in Castle Rock, where I learned about the arduous process of becoming a Chick-Fil-A franchisee and about the way federal laws are impacting small businesses. Several constituents were enjoying lunch there at the same time, so I had a chance to chat with them as well!
Enjoyed my visit with White Construction Group in Castle Rock this week. We chatted about construction industry issues and ways the federal government can facilitate economic growth.

The President's decision to withdraw from the Paris Accord is a win for Colorado. The deal disproportionately hurts the U.S. and lets the world's worst polluters off the hook. We can strive to reduce emissions in this country without participating in this poorly negotiated deal, a non-binding deal that President Obama never even sent to the Senate for approval.   From the linked article: “The Big Con at the heart of Paris is that even its supporters concede that meeting all of its commitments won’t prevent more than a 0.17 degree Celsius increase in global temperatures by 2100, far less than the two degrees that is supposedly needed to avert climate doom.”

This week I met with farmers, ranchers, and others in the Yuma community to discuss agriculture issues. Agriculture is incredibly important to our district, not only because it provides jobs for so many individuals but because everybody in this nation relies on America's farmers for nourishment.

I met with small business owners in Fort Morgan this week to talk about job creation, regulations, and how the federal government can encourage economic growth in our community. I'm eager to take their ideas back to Washington with me.

Join Congressman Ken Buck for a town hall in Castle Rock! If you have questions or comments for the Congressman this is a great chance to engage with him directly. The event will be held at Pegasus Restaurant.

Last week I had a chance to visit the Colorado Plains Regional Airport to view the on-site manufacturing and learn about the impact of FAA regulations. Infrastructure like this is important to our rural communities because it provides quality jobs and facilitates economic growth.

Last week I met with officials in Haxtun to discuss the tragic brushfires that occurred a few months ago. We talked about the recovery process, what went well, what didn't go well, and how the federal government should be involved in situations like this in the future. I'm thankful that the community truly came together in the midst of this challenge to help each other and pull through.

On this day in 1944, Allied forces launched one of the largest amphibious military operations in history: Operation Overlord. Today, we remember and thank the brave soldiers who fought to protect our nation and put an end to tyranny in Europe.  “You are about to embark upon the Great Crusade, toward which we have striven these many months. The eyes of the world are upon you. The hopes and prayers of liberty-loving people everywhere march with you.” – General Dwight D. Eisenhower
Today we're voting on the CHOICE Act, important legislation that will promote job creation and economic growth for Main Street America. Watch the video below to hear why I support this bill.

A new CMS study shows that nearly 2 million people who enrolled in Obamacare exchanges in the 2017 enrollment season have chosen not to pay their insurance premiums, letting their coverage lapse. Healthcare under Obamacare is simply too expensive for many Americans to afford the coverage they need. That’s why we need to continue working on repealing and replacing Obamacare with a system that works for all Americans.

I had the honor today of managing floor debate on the rule resolution for S. 1094, legislation that holds employees at the VA accountable for their actions and protects the whistleblowers there who expose wrongdoing. We can never fully repay our veterans for their sacrifice, but we can work on providing them quality medical care.

I applaud the administration’s work to allow American farmers to export beef and beef products to China. Cattle ranchers continue to serve an important role in the economy and this development will give them access to a $2.5 billion beef import market in China. By giving ranchers and businessmen access to markets around the world, we improve the lives of countless Americans while strengthening our nation’s position in global trade.
Praying for my colleague Majority Whip Scalise and everyone else who was injured this morning at the congressional charity baseball game practice. Still waiting for more details.

From the farmer in Prowers County to the small business owner in Longmont, we need strong local banks that can responsibly provide credit to their communities. The Financial CHOICE Act will reinvigorate community banks, helping Colorado's economy and spurring job growth.   Check out my op-ed on the bill:

I had the chance to visit with several business leaders and local officials from the 4th District at a meeting of Accelerate Colorado in DC. We talked about the achievements of this current Congress and the ways we're trying to promote economic growth for Colorado.

This week, I spoke to a group of students visiting the Capitol with Colorado Rural Electric Association. We discussed my current legislative agenda, which includes reining in government spending. Our youth shouldn't have to shoulder the burden of our current fiscal irresponsibility.
Check out this video of Scott Johnson, whom I had the honor of nominating to the U.S. Air Force Academy. Scott shares why he is so excited to serve our nation as an officer in the U.S. military.

This year, I had the honor of seeing 14 young men and women from the 4th Congressional District who I nominated to a United States Service Academy receive an offer of appointment. I'm so proud of these students, and I trust they'll rise to the challenge demanded them as officers in the U.S. military.

Today, I spoke on the floor in favor of H.R. 1654, legislation that will streamline the process of permitting water projects in Colorado.   I've been calling for reforms of this process for a long time, especially in light of the delays faced by the Northern Integrated Supply Process (NISP) in Northern Colorado.

I’m glad to see these efforts by the Department of Veterans Affairs to use taxpayer dollars wisely. The more efficient the VA’s use of resources, the better the agency will be able to serve our veterans.

I applaud the Trump Administration for proposing to repeal President Obama’s Waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) rule. The rule would have expanded federal control over local water resources, violating farmers’ and ranchers’ private property rights. State and local officials should be empowered to determine their own regulations for water resources, not Washington bureaucrats.

I learned today that 571 students from the 4th District received degrees from CU-Boulder this year. I want to congratulate all of them and the many students from the 4th District who recently graduated from other schools as well. Your hard work and perseverance make me more confident about our future.   In Washington, we need to continue searching for ways to make college accessible to all students who want to attend.

Today I voted for two bills that will make America safer. The No Sanctuary for Criminals Act denies funding to state and local governments that fail to enforce federal immigration laws. Kate's Law enhances the penalty for felons who are deported and then return to the United States.

June was Alzheimer’s & Brain Awareness Month. According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention, Alzheimer’s deaths have increased 55% between 1999 and 2014, making it the nation’s sixth-leading cause of death. Today, 5 million Americans live with Alzheimer’s and it is projected to affect 16 million Americans by 2050. We must continue the fight to end this disease. #ENDALZ

We learned this week that Minuteman Health became the latest of nineteen Obamacare CO-OPs to close its doors to patients, leaving 37,000 Americans to find a new plan for next year. In total, over 80% of these CO-OPs established under Obamacare have failed, costing taxpayers more than $2 billion. Obamacare is collapsing, and that’s why Congress is working hard to craft a replacement, one that offers access to affordable coverage for all Americans.

Today, I joined with several colleagues in requesting that Speaker Ryan cancel August recess. Leaving for August recess before we’ve completed our appropriations bills and tax reform will fail to boost our economy and imperil the people’s trust in Congress. We've been sent to Washington to work for the American people, and that's what we need to do.

I'm asking Speaker Ryan to cancel August recess unless we can get our work done. We have important tasks that the American people expect us to complete, including the annual budget, the annual appropriations process, and reforming the tax code.

We're so blessed to live in this great land, a nation that was founded on freedom and liberty. We're also so blessed by the many men and women who have fought and died for our freedom. Today, we not only remember them, we draw inspiration from their sacrifice as we go forth and fight to maintain our freedom and liberty.   Happy Independence Day!

Today, Secretary Zinke signed an order to speed up the permitting process for oil and gas development on federal lands. When statute requires applications be processed in 30 days, it shouldn't take 257, like it did during the Obama Administration. By unleashing American energy, we can create jobs in our state and improve Colorado's economy.
I've had a busy legislative year. One of the bills I've introduced is H.R. 1999, the Federal Budget Accountability Act.

Insurance options under Obamacare have dwindled for many Americans, and the latest news indicates this trend will likely continue into next year. According to the CMS, 38% fewer insurers could be participating in Obamacare exchanges in 2018. Our current healthcare system is failing, and that's why Congress is working hard on a replacement that provides affordable options to all Americans.
Washington could use some bipartisanship. That's why I introduced the Political Appointee Burrowing Protection Act with my friend from California, Democrat Rep. Ted Lieu.
If we really want to fight corruption in Washington, then we need to end the process of "burrowing." Read my recent op-ed in the Longmont Times-Call to find out more:

In Colorado, we have no choice but to wisely use our water resources. H.R. 1654 enables a more streamlined permitting process for certain water projects, helping Coloradans prepare for future growth and future water stewardship.

Our duty as Americans is to protect the vulnerable in society. That means protecting the victims and potential victims of human trafficking. This week the House passed three bills to further our fight against the evils of human trafficking.
I was deeply honored this past weekend to present a Bronze Star Medal to Mr. Doug Hendrickson for his heroic actions in Vietnam.

I had a great discussion about policy issues with folks in Larkspur a few days ago. We discussed healthcare, transportation (including I-25 widening), the need for a balanced budget, water issues, and many other topics.

Today, I voted for the National Defense Authorization Act, legislation that increases the size of our armed forces, adds maintenance funds to keep our troops safer, funds a pay raise for our troops, and keeps terrorists in Guantanamo Bay and not in America.

Colorado health insurance companies are intending to increase premium prices for individual plan customers by an average of 27% next year. We owe it to those Coloradans who may be impacted by these premium spikes to replace Obamacare with a system that actually offers affordable care.
The Arkansas Valley Conduit Project will provide fresh drinking water for Southeastern Colorado. Here's an op-ed I recently wrote about my efforts to win federal support for the project:

I recently stopped by Master Magnetics and Castle Rock Music, both in Douglas County. While there, we discussed several issues encountered by small businesses, including regulations, healthcare, and taxation. I'm fighting in Washington against the type of overreaching regulations that hurt small businesses across this country.
Had a great time with my staff at the annual hot dog lunch. Happy National Hot Dog Day!
Today, I chaired a subcommittee hearing that focused on the labor needs of the agricultural community and the ways the H-2A visa program has failed to meet that need.

This week I voted for two bills to help unleash American energy. Both pieces of legislation will help create a more transparent, streamlined permitting process, one for the domestic development of interstate natural gas pipelines and the other for the international transfer of oil, natural gas, and electricity. With an improved permitting process, American energy producers can more easily transport their products to America and the world, creating jobs and growing the American economy.
The 2017 Congressional App Challenge has officially launched! If you're a student in the 4th Congressional District, I encourage you to consider applying!  http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/

I had the honor of questioning my former professor of economics, Professor Alan Blinder, in a hearing this week about the balanced budget amendment. We both agree that things need to change in Washington to ensure this country is on a fiscally sustainable path.

"Coloradans do not care about the frivolous. We care about the meaningful."  We need to fight in Washington for meaningful policies that promote limited government, job creation, border security, and budget balancing. Read my recent op-ed in the Denver Post to hear more:

Today, we celebrate our state's 141st birthday. I'm in Washington to fight for Colorado values like hard work, independence, and family. If these values have worked for 141 years, then they can work for many more.

I recently signed on to a letter requesting the relevant committees modernize the Endangered Species Act (ESA). Only 3% of the species who have been protected by the Endangered Species Act have actually recovered to an extent that they can be de-listed. We need to replace the ESA’s one-size-fits-all approach with one that includes input from local stakeholders and experts. At the same time, we need to rethink how ESA regulations overly burden the agricultural community.

Last weekend I appreciated everyone in the Sterling and Burlington areas who came to my town halls to discuss issues. It's clear to me that Coloradans want Congress to get something done on healthcare, tax reform, and balancing the budget, so I'm only going to continue that fight back in Washington.

"'I learn so much by meeting with constituents around my district, which is why I find town halls so valuable,' he said in a statement to KUNC. 'I encourage everyone to attend one of these discussions. They give us a chance to find common ground and build consensus as a country on key issues.'”  Keep an eye on my events page for upcoming town halls. I have a few this weekend in Southeast Colorado if you're in the area: https://buck.house.gov/about/events

We've had a challenging few days in Windsor after the mill burned down over the weekend. This historic mill has been at the center of our town's history and culture for 115 years. I'm thankful no one was physically harmed by this tragedy and I thank the brave firefighters who helped battle the blaze.  Together, local government officials will work with the ATF to recover and rebuild. I know that our resilient community will emerge stronger than ever as we take this moment to plan for our future.

I was honored to join a panel today, with several of my congressional colleagues from Colorado, to discuss federal policy issues at a meeting of the Colorado Association of Commerce and Industry.   One example of the delegation working in a bipartisan way for Coloradans is the WATER Act. This legislation, which I sponsored, helps rural Coloradans have access to affordable water. I'm thankful every member of our delegation has co-sponsored this important bill.
I had a great visit to CO Mills' Sunflower Oil facility in Lamar. We discussed the need for affordable energy, infrastructure development, and limiting excessive regulations that hurt growth.

Thanks to everyone who attended my town hall in Lamar. We discussed healthcare, the importance of community health centers, tax reform, increasing care at the VA, and immigration. I always appreciate hearing feedback from constituents.
White supremacists are ignorant and hateful. All Americans must unite against racial intolerance and bigoted ideology.

Thanks to everyone who came out to discuss policy issues with me in La Junta, Springfield, Eads, Las Animas, and Lamar this month. We discussed the economy, healthcare, tax reform, agriculture, water, and many other topics--I'll be taking your ideas on these issues back to Washington with me.

We need to have more bi-partisan conversations in Washington. That's why I appreciated attending this Colorado Association of Commerce and Industry forum with my colleagues from the Colorado delegation. I've posted more photos from the event below.

Thank you to St. Vrain Valley School District, Altona Middle School, and everyone else who came together yesterday to make our first Code Day event a success. Dozens of 4th District students came out to hear about the importance of STEM education and gain hands-on experience with coding. I'm excited to see some of the amazing applications these students will produce for the Congressional App Challenge.

Today, I voted for an $8 billion aid package to assist those impacted by Hurricane Harvey. Texans have already shown their resolve, and people across our nation have come to the help of those so deeply impacted by this natural disaster. We must continue to come together as a nation in support of those Americans whose lives have been drastically altered by this storm.

America is a land of second chances. My amendment to the appropriations bill gives Americans the opportunity to have their Second Amendment rights restored. Those who have redeemed themselves should have the chance to petition for the return of their right to bear arms.  https://buck.house.gov/restoration-rights

Glad to see Secretary Sonny Perdue is working to make the United States Department of Agriculture more efficient. If you ever have trouble with the USDA or any federal agency, feel free to reach out to my office.    https://www.usda.gov/media/press-releases/2017/09/07/secretary-perdue-announces-usda-improvements-customer-service

When we say "never forget," we're honoring those who lost their lives on September 11th while also reminding ourselves who we want to be in the future. To truly remember those dark days is to live with the same courage, resolve, vigilance, and compassion that overflowed onto the streets of New York and elsewhere after the attacks. Only that kind of passion for the American cause and the American people will keep this Republic alive.
Our country has a spending problem. A big spending problem. And the consequences will be borne by our children and grandchildren if we don't change the way things work in Washington.

Hispanic Heritage Month starts on September 15. For the 4th Congressional District, that means we have a chance to honor the many Hispanic-Americans who have contributed to our communities over the years. Help my office recognize those who have been part of this heritage by sharing their stories here:

The State Criminal Alien Assistance Program (SCAAP) helps local law enforcement pay for the incarceration of undocumented criminal aliens with at least one felony or two misdemeanor convictions. But some of these municipalities have adopted sanctuary policies, allowing violent offenders to go free. I just offered an amendment to the appropriations bill to cut off SCAAP money if these funds aren't being used appropriately.

Are you a student in the 4th Congressional District who codes? If so, then you should participate in the Congressional App Challenge! This competition is a great opportunity to build up your Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math skillset. And if that's not enough, winners will also:   - Be eligible to have their app featured in the Capitol Building - Be eligible to have their app placed on House.gov. - Receive $250 in Amazon Web Services (AWS) Credits - Be invited to the #HouseOfCode Washington, DC Reception

I'm so encouraged by the students I met at Up-A-Creek-Robotics in Longmont. This district-wide high school robotics team invests hundreds of hours competing in a national competition. In the process they develop Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) skills that will propel them into future careers. STEM education should be a key part of the discussion on education policy.

I recently co-sponsored the National Right to Work Act, legislation that empowers workers and that will contribute to economic and job growth. This important bill removes the language in the federal code that forces all employees to pay union dues or else lose their job. Freedom of association is a two-way street, and no American should be forced by the federal government to join a union.

Thank you to everyone who attended my town hall this past weekend in Castle Rock. We discussed issues ranging from healthcare to tax reform to immigration and border security. I greatly appreciate conversations like these with constituents, because they equip me to better fight for the 4th Congressional District's priorities when I'm back in Washington.

I recently had the opportunity to deliver remarks at an Honor Flight Northern Colorado ceremony. I couldn't be prouder or more honored to speak to that group of men and women. Their actions, their courage, their bravery saved our country and the world. This ceremony was also extra special. Among the participants on the flight were my wife, Perry, and her father, Bill Webster, who served in the Korean War.

We all know Hispanic Americans who have contributed in big ways to the 4th Congressional District. During Hispanic Heritage Month, help my office recognize those who have been part of this heritage by sharing their stories here: https://buck.house.gov/hispanic-heritage-month

Do you know Hispanic Americans who have made big contributions to their communities in the 4th Congressional District? In honor of Hispanic Heritage Month, I'm collecting their stories. Please share them here: https://buck.house.gov/hispanic-heritage-month

We all know that D.C. is broken. I recently had the chance to sit down with Sharyl Attkisson on her show, Full Measure. We talked about Washington disfunction--from the influence of money in politics to the funding of unauthorized programs. I encourage you to watch the interview tomorrow. Check the below link for a list of stations and to catch the show online after it airs.
I'm praying for all of those impacted by the evil events in Las Vegas last night. Our country must stand together in support of the families of the victims and the community.

I didn't come to Washington to make friends. I came to represent the 4th Congressional District, and that means exposing the dysfunction that plagues this city.   Watch my interview below to hear more.

Last night, I supported legislation that protects unborn children across America. At 20 weeks, an unborn baby can feel pain and even has a chance for survival outside of the womb. We have a responsibility to the unborn children, our families, our communities, and humanity to end the injustice of late-term abortion.

Congrats to Jason Santomaso, from Sterling, who was named the Runner-Up Champion at the World Livestock Auctioneering Contest a few days ago. He'll be competing in the world championship of livestock auctioneering next summer in Wisconsin. I'm proud to have someone representing the proud agricultural tradition of our district on the world stage.
Join me tonight at 7 PM MT for a Facebook Live town hall. I'm eager to sit down with Rep. Paul Gosar to discuss important issues.
Watch my Facebook Live town hall with Rep. Gosar happening right now!
On National Farmers Day, we have a chance to remember and thank farmers for the many contributions they make not only to our agricultural economy and food supply but also to our communities.
Happy Birthday to the U.S. Navy! Thank you to all who have served.

Had a great conversation with the US Travel Association and business leaders from Northern Colorado today. We've seen important economic successes in our district, but we need to remain focused on policies that create jobs. Tax reform is a key part of that effort, which is why I'm fighting for a tax code reform that is simple, fair, and designed for economic growth.

Today, I sat down with several veterans who have struggled to receive the care they need from an overly bureaucratic, poorly managed Veterans Affairs Administration. Many of their stories are heartbreaking. My office is working hard to make breakthroughs for them, but we're also pushing for reforms that will provide better care and greater choice for all our heroes. These men and women sacrificed for our nation, and now they deserve so much more than they've been getting from the VA.

Just under two weeks left for you to submit your app to the Congressional App Challenge! If you're a student in the 4th Congressional District, this is a great opportunity to develop your Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math skills and potentially show off your app in Washington, D.C.! For more information, go to http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/. #code #STEM #CongressionalAppChallenge

When extremists attack our energy infrastructure, they put our families, communities, and the environment at risk. That's why I led a bi-partisan letter to Attorney General Jeff Sessions, signed by 83 of my colleagues, asking him about the DOJ's efforts to prosecute the individuals involved in past attacks and the department's plans for future prosecutions.  Read the letter here: https://buck.house.gov/sites/buck.house.gov/files/wysiwyg_uploaded/Protecting%20Energy%20Infrastructure.pdf

Damaging America's energy infrastructure is not only illegal, it's potentially fatal. The Americans who live around and rely daily on this infrastructure deserve the opportunity to feel safe in their homes. That's why I'm leading a letter to Attorney General Sessions to find out what the DOJ is doing to prosecute individuals who have attacked our energy pipelines. I'm thankful to the 83 Members of Congress who also signed on to this bi-partisan letter.

I just voted for the Stop Settlement Slush Funds Act. This important legislation permanently stops an Obama administration practice where the Department of Justice required donations to liberal, third-party, outside groups as part of settlement agreements. Basically, the administration was using settlements to fund its pet political causes instead of returning those dollars to actual lawsuit victims or the taxpayer. No DOJ should ever have the opportunity to use settlements for political gain. I’m thankful Attorney General Sessions has ended this practice. H.R. 732 allows us to permanently abolish this practice.

Yesterday, I voted to restore Article I powers to Congress by voting for H.R. 469. This legislation shores up legislative branch power in a few ways, but I wanted to highlight one in particular.   Often times, consent decrees and settlement agreements require federal agencies to create new rules without the impacted stakeholders having a say in the litigation process. This legislation allows job creators and state regulators to have a fair opportunity to participate in the creation of new rules. Regulations should come from the regulatory process through faithful implementation of statutes, not from litigation.

Are you competing in the Congressional App Challenge? If so, remember to submit your apps by tomorrow at 10 AM MT! For more information on the challenge, visit http://www.congressionalappchallenge.us/
I'm praying tonight for those impacted by this attack in Thornton.

The House of Representatives has passed over 300 bills that are now stalled in the Senate. Last night I took to the floor with several of my colleagues to highlight House accomplishments and call on the Senate to act.   The dreams of this great Republic cannot be realized by the House alone. The Senate must hear the people and come together around the often bi-partisan measures we’ve been sending to them.

I led an hour this week on the House floor, with several of my colleagues, urging the Senate to act. The House has now passed over 300 bills that are stalled in the upper chamber. The American people deserve better.
Got to meet a new constituent earlier this week.

I recently had the opportunity to speak in Longmont with the St. Vrain Valley School District Student Senate, a group of high school students who meet to learn about Colorado's legislative process and offer input on legislation. We discussed several issues, including tax reform and healthcare. I'm proud that these students are so civically engaged and I'm confident many of them will be leaders of our community and nation in a few decades.

Hollywood and the entertainment industry have a serious cultural problem. For years they've turned a blind eye to the criminal conduct of sexual predators.  Congress must not. Read my thoughts on this issue and the way Congress should be involved:

The House recently passed important legislation that allows first responders to administer pain relievers, under guidance from doctors, while a patient is in transport to a hospital. This important change is especially important for rural Colorado, where ambulance rides can sometimes last hours.
For years, Hollywood has turned a blind eye to sexual abuse and harassment. Congress must not. The federal government should not be subsidizing an industry that engages in this kind of behavior.

"Freedom only exists because a people believe in it, because of the men and women who have fought for it. American values only exist because our neighbors follow them, because our grandparents and parents went to war to uphold them. Our Constitution only survives because our government abides by it, and because American heroes spilled blood for it."  Yesterday, I attended a lunch in honor of the 242nd anniversary of the Marine Corps. The individuals there inspired me, but I always feel like we can never do enough to honor veterans in a way they deserve.   So this year I shared my thoughts in a letter that was read at Veterans Day events around the district. Read the rest of it at the link below. And take time to thank and honor the veterans around you.
As we rethink our tax code, we need to rethink the way Congress treats Hollywood. Taxpayers should not be subsidizing an institution that covers up sexual assault and harassment.

I supported the National Defense Authorization Act tonight to keep our country secure and to take care of our troops. The bill strengthens our military and includes the largest pay raise our troops have seen in 8 years.

I'm leading an effort to end tax subsidies for the hush money paid by Hollywood companies to victims of sexual assault and sexual harassment. I'm hopeful the language from my amendment will be included in the final tax package so that taxpayers are no longer forced to subsidize this misconduct in any industry.

Today I supported a tax bill that I believe is the first step towards growing our economy and creating jobs. We must follow-up this historic legislation by reducing federal spending and reducing regulations on small business.
Robin and Dusty from my district office met with Disabled American Veterans (DAV) Chapter No. 41 at the County Steak Out in Fort Morgan this week to discuss important veterans issues.

I'm fighting to see language included in the tax reform bill that prohibits taxpayer dollars from subsidizing hush money payments in sexual assault and sexual harassment cases. No industry or institution can turn a blind eye to this kind of misconduct.

I have so many things to be thankful for on this Thanksgiving Day. So I wrote about them in this column: https://www.greeleytribune.com/news/opinion/buck-take-time-today-to-be-thankful-for-all-we-have/  Take this time of thanksgiving to truly appreciate those people around you who make our community and this country thrive.

Tomorrow is Small Business Saturday. Small businesses form the backbone of our economy and our communities. That's why it's so important for Congress to create an environment where these local businesses can thrive.

Today is Small Business Saturday, a chance for us to remember the important contributions that local businesses make to our economy and our communities. During the month of November I've visited several small businesses in the 4th Congressional District to discuss ways in which Washington can create a better environment for local businesses to thrive. Here are some photos from those visits.

Had a great visit to Nichols Tillage Tools yesterday in Sterling. We need to reform the tax code and push for better internet access in rural Colorado to help companies like these grow and create jobs.

After 77 days, the House's 12 appropriations bills are still languishing in the Senate. The upper chamber of Congress needs to get to work, because the American people deserve a thoughtful budget and spending process, not a cobbled together omnibus spending bill written in a smoke-filled room.

Proud to co-sponsor the Congressional Accountability and Hush Fund Elimination Act, which prohibits the use of public, taxpayer funds to settle sexual assault and sexual harassment claims. This kind of misconduct is inappropriate wherever it happens.
78 days and counting. Still waiting for the Senate to act on the appropriations bills the House sent over. Americans deserve a thoughtful budget process, not an omnibus.
The Senate needs to get its act together.

I just voted to take another step in the process of reforming our tax system. We need a simpler, fairer tax code that empowers individuals to make decisions with their own money and that allows business owners to invest in growth and job creation. Thank you to everyone who has called my office and emailed me with suggestions for how to improve our tax code. I'm eager for the conferees to work out a final package that truly improves the quality of life for all Coloradans.

Today, I launched the Congressional Reformers Caucus with my co-chair and friend, Rep. Kathleen Rice. We lead this caucus together, one Republican and one Democrat, because we believe that by working across the aisle, we can fight for reforms to Congress and the legislative process that make government work better for the people.   Learn more here: https://buck.house.gov/congressional-reformers-caucus

“Washington is broken. Donors and insiders have too much influence, and too often backroom deals trip up good legislation. Political party has nothing to do with good governance, which is why I’m proud to be joined by my friend, Rep. Kathleen Rice, and a bipartisan group of colleagues who all want a Congress that works for the people.”  Read more here:
This is one of those days we must never forget.

This week, the House unanimously passed the Taylor Force Act, important legislation that prevents foreign aid from being used by the Palestinian Authority to make payments to convicted terrorists and their families. U.S. tax dollars should never end up in the hands of terrorists.

I'm excited to announce the winners of the 4th Congressional District's Congressional App Challenge! Congratulations to Evan Hassman and Hunter Burley, Erie High School students who took first place with their app, “In Space, Out of Gas.”

America has a responsibility to our allies, to ourselves, to freedom-loving countries around the world to fight back against Iran's evil behavior in the Middle East. If we want peace and stability in that region of the world, then we must stop money and resources from flowing into the hands of Iranian-backed terrorists.

I'm so glad that the VA has decided to start offering Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy as an option for veterans dealing with severe injuries. I've been working on this issue for quite a while now and am thankful to the veterans, providers, VA officials, and my colleagues who have invested their time and energy into making this a reality. I will continue working to improve veterans' access to this therapy.

I voted today for the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act because it makes the tax code simpler and fairer for American families, it encourages companies to keep jobs in America through a more equitable business tax rate, and it offers lower taxes for Americans.
Merry Christmas! Today, I thank God for family, for community, and for the Son he sent to the world to be our savior.
Praying for those impacted by the events in Highlands Ranch this morning.
Join Congressman Ken Buck in Eads! If you have questions or comments for the Congressman this is a great chance to engage with him directly. The event will be held at the Cobblestone Inn & Suites.

Join Congressman Ken Buck for a town hall in Sterling! If you have questions or comments for the Congressman this is a great chance to engage with him directly. The event will be held in the Sterling Public Library.

Join Congressman Ken Buck for a town hall in Lamar! If you have questions or comments for the Congressman this is a great chance to engage with him directly. The event will be held in the Cultural Events Center.
